commentBody:
Broken link again, again.

This was my favorite kind of Friday puzzle ‚Äî tough, fair, clever, fun, and mysterious. Lots of tricky clues that had me guessing until they managed to solve themselves (I take no credit).

Looking forward to more from this duo!
Fun. Tough. Great clues. Had to check names, as always. A great way to start the solving weekend. Thanks, Adrian & Jess! Y‚Äôall have a great Friday!

The Griddies*, 2025

Each year volunteers work to bestow awards on the year's best puzzles. Please read this message for information on how to nominate puzzles and how to vote for them.  Eric Hougland and I will coordinate the voting, hoping for a third volunteer, though! 

There will be two rounds of voting. In the first round, you‚Äôll be able to vote for more than one puzzle in a category. The puzzles with the highest number of first-round votes will then move to a second round, where you'll vote for your favorite in each category.

December 11 - January 8: Nominations
1/11 - 1/16: Voting on First Round
1/18 - 1/25: Voting for Second (Final) Round¬†
2/1: Announcement of winners & runners-up

CATEGORIES:
¬†
Early week (M-W)
Thursday Themeless
¬†F-S)
Sunday

NOMINATIONS

You can REPLY to any message of this kind with your nominations (as many as you like in each category) and we'll gather them from there. A future announcement will also include a dedicated email for nominations, too, if you wish. Nominations should include the puzzle date and constructor. Optional: a brief statement as to why it's POY material: standout themes, clues, etc. 

VOTING

We'll use a custom-made ballot on an outside website. The ballot is easy to use and will allow for voting on each of the four categories. We‚Äôll provide a link when voting begins. Nominating & Voting is open to all.

More details to follow. But start nominating, everyone!

-- Eric Hougland
-- john ezra

*Name thanks to Vaer!

This one didn't seem *too* tough.  Well below my Friday average but not a PB.  Never heard CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE in my life that I can recall.  But CRISSCROSS seemed obvious enough and with crosses (pun intended) the rhyme mostly filled itself in.  I can never remember whether the 2010 Jobs announcement is IPAD OR IPOD lol.  And TIL a new (to me) word SAPID.  Enjoyed it!

Thank you, Jess and Adrian for a fresh and inventive grid!  Chewy enough to be satisfying, but not too much of a [Rocky Road].  As for the two truths and a lie challenge, my guess is that one of you does not find ice cream to be entirely SAPID.
Perhaps I vibed with the authors because that felt pretty easy (right in the middle between PB and my average). Fun puzzle, a lot of good words!
I found this puzzle SAPID because I learned a new word!!

Well this made up for my disappointment with yesterday‚Äôs puzzle.  Oddly enough I completed in about the same time as yesterday‚Äôs. But it felt consistently fresh and surprising, with lots of fun entries like TINFOILHAT, ASSEENONTV, CULTSTATUS and LABPARTNER It was just one of those times when I was on the same wavelength as the constructor.  

I was helped immeasurably by the fact I knew CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE, by having to remind my grandson on numerous occasions to sit that way and not in his preferred posture with his legs splayed to the sides.

I was also helped tremendously by the reference to RILKE, who is definitely in the upper echelon of my personal pantheon of poets. His poem Autumn Day has haunted me decades:

Lord: it is time.  The summer was immense.
Lay your shadow on the sundials
And let loose the wind in the fields.

Bid the last fruits to be full;
Give them yet two southerly days,
Press them to fullness, and force
The last sweetness into the heavy wine.

Whoever has no house now will not build  one
Whoever is alone now will long remain so,
Will stay up, read, write long letters,
And wander the avenues, up and down,
Restlessly, while the leaves are blowing
For approximately 3 nanoseconds I wanted ORIGAMI to be ‚Äúfrom the Greek‚Äù, ha.

After what was widely acknowledged as a misplaced Tuesday puzzle yesterday, many were hoping (fearing?) we might get our comeuppance today... Alas, this "Friday" puzzle was merely 2 minutes more difficult than yesterday's. Re 26D, unfortunately, visitors to the USA may soon need to give up all their privacy for a tourist VISA: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/12/09/travel/social-media-tourists-visa-border-patrol.html?unlocked_article_code=1.8E8.BOIi.lHnTllSD0x6T&smid=url-share

Some random musings:

10D could have been my first choice, POTHOLE, which I think makes for more of a rocky road than ASPHALT.  I'm sure you can stretch the meaning of asphalt to make it rocky, but it's a petroleum product, which is rolled smooth, not rocky at all.  Not saying it's an invalid clue, just that my original answer seems more apt.  

But wait, THERE'S MORE...(AS SEEN ON TV) 

CRISS CROSS APPLESAUCE is what they used to call "Indian style."  I'm not sure which type of Indian--Native American or Asian--was offended, but apparently someone was, and the phrase disappeared.  The "applesauce" part of the name is just silly rhyme, but the "criss cross" is a minced version of "Christ's cross," so I wouldn't be surprised if Christians are now offended.  

Now VALENCIA is (correctly) the orange city; about two weeks ago, SEVILLE had the honor.  Apparently, there are a lot of oranges in Spain.  I KNOW, RIGHT?

8D: I remember Bobby Kennedy (the original one) having been quoted as saying that.  I guess he just ripped it off old Bernard.

Have a fun weekend, everyone.

I have a moral dilemma best put to the sage, measured, and never-snarky NYT Crossword Commentariat.  My situation: On Tuesday, I went to bed after completing the Wednesday puzzle.  I possessed my usual self-satisfaction, smugly content my 500+ puzzle streak was intact.  To my alarm, on Wednesday, I realized I had forgotten to do the Tuesday puzzle, and after I did it, I observed an ugly blue square in my archive of golden boxes.  After moping around for two days and being rightfully made fun of by my wife, I ask you: Is my streak over?  If it is, should I pretend it is not?

On the one hand, if it‚Äôs over, my family/friends will be better off.  No longer will they have to feign being impressed or even interested when I work my streak into a conversation about their cat.  Likewise, I‚Äôll feel better not having to deal with eye rolls and sarcasm every time I tell them how hard the Saturday puzzle was.  I‚Äôll also get sweet release‚Äîno longer will I carry that streak ball-and-chain; instead, I can focus on politics, current events, and other non-distressful things.  

On the other hand, Tuesdays are gimmes, and I did one puzzle each day.  Why should I lose my streak if they were switched?  Also, facts don‚Äôt matter‚Äîhaving been alive the last 10 years, I now know they don't exist, and I can live in my own reality.  Lots of people do!

But the best argument is‚Äîno one cares! Really, no one cares about my dumb streak.  Even my mom is over it.

What say you, Commentariat?
Nominating 28D for Clue of the Week

Last night was easy bad.
Tonight was easy good!

No idea exactly how that works, but I guarantee I‚Äôm not the only one who feels it.

A:  Living near Fallingwater is so great!

B:  I kno', Wright?

___

Rilke first started the Duino Elegies, a cycle of 10 longish poems, while staying as a guest of Princes Thurn und Taxis at Duino Castle, on the Adriatic Sea in 1912. He did not complete the cycle until 1922 -- the war intervened, and Rilke, intense and sensitive to begin with, was deeply affected by the suffering and death he witnessed, and it shaped his notions of his own existence and its meaning, themes he had already begun to explore back in 1912 --  thus the poems reflected this journey through time and his evolving conceptions of humanity and of the divine; the poems were published in 1923, dedicated to the Princess. 

ELEGY # 10 (1st stanza)

Some day, in the emergence from this fierce insight,

let me sing jubilation and praise to assenting Angels.

Let not a single one of the cleanly-struck hammers of my heart

deny me, through a slack, or a doubtful, or

a broken string. Let my streaming face

make me more radiant: let my secret weeping

bear flower. O, how dear you will be to me, then, Nights

of anguish. Inconsolable sisters, why did I not

kneel more to greet you, lose myself more

in your loosened hair? We, squanderers of pain.

How we gaze beyond them into duration‚Äôs sadness,

to see if they have an end. Though they are nothing but

our winter-suffering foliage, our dark evergreen,

one of the seasons of our inner year ‚Äì not only

season - but place, settlement, camp, soil, dwelling.
Regarding the 2 truths and a lie: I think someone doesn‚Äôt like ice cream as much as they could‚Ä¶
Also, I haven't eaten Rocky Road ice cream in probably 20 years, so IDK if I was sane in having SEASALT there for so long in place of ASPHALT... Is sea salt even in Rocky Road Ice Cream?? LOL

Despite entering it many times in puzzles. I've never had an ICEE (or even seen one in real life). In my imagination it was not a drink but more like the Italian ice of my childhood that the local store would serve us kids with an ice cream scoop. TIL.
New PB today for REVEAL PUZZLE!

Ok, Adrian and Jess, I think lie is one of you works at a high school and the other at a college. I enjoyed your puzzle and worked at a clip until I got to the 37A and 33D junction. I started at g_at for a kid‚Äôs parent for the longest time.

A new Friday best! And 2m faster than my Thursday best. But, judging from other comments, I am not the only solver who sprinted through
this puzzle. So maybe I'll save that bottle of champagne for a more hard-won victory!

DIPLOMA is one of my favorite word origins to share with people. One can almost imagine an ambassador presenting their (folded) credentials at the palace gate, and being called a "diplomat" in jest.

I quite enjoyed this. Not the most difficult Friday but actually a nice mix of accessibility and challenge. There were a smattering of some easier clues, which will help the less experienced solver, but not enough to spoil the fun for more experienced ones. Some clever clues‚ÄîLABPARTNER, ASPHALT, some new terms for me‚ÄîSAPID and the delightful CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE, not part of my childhood‚Äîand a quote I hadn‚Äôt  heard from my favorite playwright, SHAW. I found this a well balanced Friday and I got a kick out of it.

I found this a proper Friday challenge.

I managed to fill the grid without lookups, even though it was full of unknowns. CRISSCROSS was easily gettable but APPLESAUCE confused me. I entered it, very hesitantly, once crosses indicated what it would be, but I don't get it. Is the only reason for the latter phrase being there that it rhymes with the former? Anyway, in Polish sitting with ones legs folded is "siedzieƒá po turecku," literally "sitting Turkish" (unlike English speakers, we don't use capital letters in adjectives derived from proper names).

I had to guess FEDEX based just on the final X, and it was similar with SHAW and RILKE: I knew the names but not the quote or title, so I had to rely on crosses and trust myself to enter the missing letters.

For a minute I wondered if there might be a Friday rebus, because the only rapper Banks I am familiar with is Azealia.

I did an alphabet run for the crossing of SAPI(D) and (D)ART.

"Asfalt" is the only Polish word to describe an oil-based road surface, and since I am not familiar with American ice cream types, the entry of ASPHALT was very easy for me. I don't think I've ever seen it here before though, and I've done well over 1000 NYT crossword puzzles.

I'm missing something. SEN?? üôÉ
Thanks.
Filling in CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE first was nice, and everything else falling into place was nicer, though I struggled with what a HASP is. Good puzzle :)

I loved this puzzle for its variety, from the TINFOIL HAT to Rainer Maria and (p)SHAW, and all the TV ACTS and vaudeville SKITS‚Äîwhat a trip!  It was never boring and just enough challenge to make a Friday puzzle fun. 

Thank you, Adrian and Jess. I suspect you had as much fun constructing it as I did solving it.  Nice collaboration.

I‚Äôve been taking longer lately to do the puzzle on my phone, partly because of my many typos. But yesterday went by quite swiftly, and today was my fastest for a long time. Intentional trickery like rocky road ingredient just has come to feel obvious.

I‚Äôve watched a lot of cooking videos from Italia Squisita, so ‚Äòsapidita‚Äô was somewhat familiar to me. It was still the last clue I filled in though.

Very fun puzzle and a decent challenge for a Friday.

Deb, my crabs Shed before MOLTing. 
CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE came to me magically from somewhere with practically no letters filled in and really broke the puzzle open.  I don't have kids that would have learned it. I recently rewatched Kindergarten Cop, so that might have been it.  The movie is very funny and Arnold's supporting cast, which includes Pamela Reed as his partner and Linda Hunt as the school principal, is terrific.

I was going back over the archives, and I ran across a Sunday puzzle about a year ago, 12/18/24.  For some reason I had a couple weeks of missing ones in that time span.

It was the most extraordinary puzzle.  It was called "Art Heist" by David Kwong, and it was brilliant.  There were 1500 comments, all saying it was the best puzzle they'd ever seen, or ever expected to see.

Of course I jest.  I've seen it mentioned here, usually with the adjective of "infamous", if not worse.

It was a puzzle I was never going to get a gold star on (given I missed it at the time), so I was unpressured and actually *really* enjoyed it.  

I got out a pen and paper and had to logically go through the puzzle, and after a false start or two (or a hundred) I eventually figured it out, although it took me roughly 2400 hours.  (I didn't know the clock could go so high.)

Anyway, blast from the past.
Aww don't leave us hanging--which statement is the lie? I'm guessing #3.
This puzzle was a mixed bag for me. Lots of gimmes (TINFOIL HAT, VALENCIA, FONDANT), lots of whu-huhs (T STOP, RILKE, SAPID). In other words, a perfectly fair Friday.

"You want some apples?"
"Nah, I don't core for them."

("What about applesauce?"
"Now Mott's more like it!")
Good puzzle! However, a lot of guesswork from my end to complete it. Many things I didn't know and guessed as working around the answers (mostly names, though I did know the Shaw quote.)

This was pretty straightforward for me. Any issues were confidently crossed. RILKE was novel, but finished the crosses with MONEYTREE which was also a new one but it couldn‚Äôt have been anything else at that point.

I‚Äôm not sure if I would have known FONDANT in my younger days but I have a friend who went to culinary school in NYC and specializes in cakes. My favorite of her designs is her recreation of Van Gogh‚Äôs ‚ÄúStarry Night‚Äù in fondant.

Also, I‚Äôve only seen pictures of it, but she made a replica of St. Patrick‚Äôs Cathedral out of gingerbread as her school final project. Stained glass windows, spires, the works. Absolutely brilliant.

Alas, she doesn‚Äôt do it anymore. It was hard to make a go of it when one sells a cake for $500, the ingredients are $600 with 50 hours oh time invested. It was truly art what she did.

This puzzle made me smile, so thanks for that gift, Jess and Adrian ! And speaking of gifts, you gave me the perfect gift-giving idea for the conspiracy theorists in my family. Happy Holidays ! I'm a retired elementary school teacher, so CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE brought back great memories. I miss those kids ! Finally, today I learned a new-to-me word, SAPID. So pleased was this lifelong learner with the word, he used it for his Wordle start word. (don't recommend)

Service returned to normal. 

A good Friday workout. 

TIANA was totally unknown as was the CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE but they were getable from the crossings and lack of plausible alternatives. 

the D in SAPID was the last to fall. Still not accustomed to thinking that US football is played with one‚Äôs hands. 

Thanks.

This was a brilliant crossword. And I‚Äôm grateful to the setters for turning my attention to RILKE. What a beautiful mind he seems to be. Some quotes from the poet:

‚ÄúAh, how good it is to be among people who are reading‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is spring again. The earth is like a child that knows poems by heart‚Äù

‚ÄúLove consists of this: two solitudes that meet, protect and greet each other.‚Äù

Rilke (1875-1925) has touched my heart.

"And, most important, we will inhale as much chocolate as needed in order to keep our energy up throughout the solving process."

Deb, you are the best.

Very nice, fairly straightforward but thoroughly enjoyable. I only got stuck on the TOE/GOAT pair, where I couldn't see past TeE/GeAT. Too early in the morning to make the kid-goat connection (lovely clue) and, even as a keen recreational golfer back in my Scotland days, never used or heard the term "toe" as part of a golf club.
Great work, thanks Adrian!

FONDANT/TIANA was a Natick here.  And only here, apparently.

Gotta get out more.

A fine Friday.

Liked this, I did. It's unusual for me to complete a Friday or Saturday without look-ups so I'm always proud of myself when I do. And 5m30s faster than normal time too. Pats himself on the back.

SAPID/DART was left till the end, but even when I decided that made more sense than SAPIc/cART, there was still no music. It was only when I looked through that I realised ScOOT/cASPS should probably be SHOOT/HASPS. Perhaps I should fake-swear or fasten things more often ü§î

CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE 
is just plain fun.

AND THERES MORE‚Ä¶so *much* more to love
in this puppy. 
And if you don‚Äôt love FONDANT,
I‚Äôm not sure we can be friends.

Hubby was doing okay per his last text at 11 last night.
Don‚Äôt love waking up without him here, 
but he is in very good hands 
and covered with wires to keep his heart monitored.

Thank you all for the kindness, prayers,
and support yesterday.

Just writing that makes 
my eyes leak a little bit.

I appreciate you all.

Hug ‚Äòem if you got ‚Äòem.
I scored today by guessing the word SAPID, which I've never heard before. After I read Deb's etymology of it, however, it made sense to me. I'll allow it.
After my first pass, I was at the bottom of the puzzle before finding something to fill. Somehow it came together though in under average time. Never say never...

‚ÄúPuzzle may cause a reaction, or contain things last seen on an old TV. And it is not a toy. Or a diploma.‚Äù

I thought it was ‚Äúcrisscross applause‚Äù because yay, I managed to get into that position at my age, here‚Äôs hoping I can get out of it.
Nice puzzle.

FONDANT brings back memories of a cake I use to buy in the 70's.  Macy's had a bakery back then and they had a rum cake wrapped in hot pink FONDANT with the word "rum" written in script on the top.  

When they stopped making it, I found the bakery that made it for them.  When the bakery went out of business, I looked for recipes, with no success.

Once the internet came along, I resumed my search.  It seems that it was based on an Austrian cake called punschtorte.  I tried every recipe I could find, but none matched the perfection of the original.

This cake was so good, that once, after serving it to company, there was a small piece left on the plate of one guest.  When they went home, I ate it.  I don't usually do things like that.  The cake was that special.

Lovely moments.  
‚Ä¢	That Shaw quote, which I haven‚Äôt thought about in ages. 
‚Ä¢	Filling in GOAT, which tripped off yesterday‚Äôs [Pan in the butt?].
‚Ä¢	Inner smiles at uncovering: I KNOW, RIGHT? / AS SEEN ON TV / CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE / CULT STATUS / SAPID.  

Such moments add beauty and joy not only to the box, but to the entire day.  This was more than just a fill-in.

I also loved being misdirected by [Doesn‚Äôt just talk], where I was thinking, ‚ÄúYaks?‚Äù ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúGabs?‚Äù  Not to mention the serendipity of a backward WAHS in the grid with SOB, clued [Waaaaah!].

Felt like a pre-holiday gift, for which I‚Äôm eminently grateful.  I‚Äôm strongly hoping for more from the J&J team!

I just got the "Solve Friday‚Äôs Crossword on Easy Mode!" email, and 45D / 60A are incorrect.

I completed the Friday in normal mode earlier today, but I'm always interested to see how they clue the same answers, differently.
My first gold star on a Friday!
I‚Äôm a gardener but I don‚Äôt know what a dart stain is. 60 Across

Very easy for a Friday.

On the other hand I have a love-hate relationship with Connections. ü§™
5D  38A bring to mind the fabulous Miss Frazzled!

A fun workout. Many thanks. As Steve L. and others mentioned last night I also immediately thought of the RFK quote which became this morning's rabbit hole: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy%27s_remarks_at_the_University_of_Kansas And the Shaw source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Back_to_Methuselah Seems the connection was Shaw>JFK>RFK.

I never heard of CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE, but I did know SAPID. I used to speak Italian really well, and I think "sapere" means "to taste" in that language as well as Latin. I never realized that it was the opposite of "insipid," so thanks, Deb.

But I was thrown a bit by the clue for 54A, because my recollection is of seeing it on the front of boxes and packages, not on the side. After getting AS* and wondering what was going on, it was a slam dunk once I got ETRE and VET.

Please excuse any typos. I always try to proofread, but I'm having some severe vision problems that I can only hope will get better. I can barely see what I've typed, and doing the puzzle is getting nearly impossible. Oh, the joys of aging.
The puzzles have, on the whole, been exceptionally easy lately. It's been a long time since we've had a truly challenging puzzle that isn't full of arcane trivia.
You had me with "Conspiracy theorist's accessory." loved it...and the remaining clues. Many thanks Adrian and Jess for a great Friday puzzle!

Typical tough Friday for me. Had to look up a couple of things, but then just a lot of working the crosses until something dawned on me. Ended up being an enjoyable workout. Rather amazing puzzle find today - a Thursday from August 21, 2003 by Patrick Merrell. Six rebus squares in that one - each of them consisting of two alternating letters. A couple of examples: 2d: CR(I/O)SS crossing... 17a T(I/O)P so, the implied answers were CRISSCROSS and TIPTOP A couple of other examples; FL(I/O)P crossing P(I/O)NG T(I/O)CK crossing H(I/O)PPITY AT(I/A)SKET crossing W(I/A)SHY And some other implied answers - RIFF/RAFF CHIT/CHAT ZIG/ZAG KNICK/KNACK Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/21/2003&g=2&d=D ...

When I saw the clue "One way to sit", I thought the answer might be "pat" or "tight".  When I saw how many letters it had, my first thought was CRISCROSS APPLESAUCE.  And when I saw that it fit and the crossing S was in the right place, I confidently put it in.
My first answer in today's puzzle!

When I was a kid, we didn't sit like that; we sat "Indian style".  A brief moment of silence for that phrase, please.

CRISS-CROSS APPLESAUCE is not new around here.

Kate Hawkins August 16, 2024 puzzle clued SIT with

[Something to do "criss-cross applesauce"]

That's where I learned it.

We used to sit cross-legged.
Loved today's crossword!  If my wife wasn't a primary school teacher I'd never have solved one way to sit.  Lots of puns in this puzzle-loved it!

PR Friday, 22:42, another whopping 31:53 better than my average! PR for two days in a row! Maybe solving first thing in the morning helps. Probably just the right wavelength match with the setter. BATHTUB got me for a while.

Rainer Maria RILKE ranks among the greatest poets of the 20th century.  His late poems ("The Sonnets to Orpheus" and "Duino Elegies" are notoriously difficult.  His earlier poems, however, are very approachable and gorgeous.

Here's the opening stanza of Alone in the World" (translated by A.S. Kidder):

I am much too alone in this world, yet not alone
    enough
to truly consecrate the hour.
I am much too small in this world, yet not small
    enough
to be to you just object and thing,
dark and smart.
I want my free will and want it accompanying
the path which leads to action;
and want during times that beg questions,
where something is up,
to be among those in the know,
or else be alone.

I learned such a lot with this crossword! From 1A onwards. I knew ETTA but not ERICA, but I knew your ASPHALT is my tarmac (tar McAdam). 

When a teacher, I said "cross your legs" and not anything else, but when I was a child  "Indian file" was used for single file. 

There were quite a few words I only got with crossers. ANNE Applebaum is an excellent writer about European history.

Very enjoyable.
How many of us looked up the FedEx logo?

I found this a delightful puzzle. Others have already pointed out some of the enjoyable clues. Thanks, Adrian and Jess.

Had trouble with SAPID as I‚Äôd a) never heard it, and b) was sure 53A was bINS.
Got CRISSCROSS APPLESAUCE immediately, though had them reversed in the across/down positions so ripped them out then got to re-enter them later in a forehead slap moment.

[Era before shoes were invented]

Fun puzzle.





RAW FOOT AGE
Unlike so many others, I didn't find this puzzle easy.  I needed fifteen of Christina Iverson's alternate 'easy' clues.  Thank you, Christina, for creating them!

I suppose when I think of a perfect puzzle, this would be a good example, in my opinion! Excellent cluing, fairly straightforward, very few proper names, and most of all fun! Happy Friday everyone!!!!!

PIPS QUESTION: Has anyone else noticed the timer is way off for the medium puzzle? When I finished the medium today, it said it took me 1:02:35. It took me a few minutes but definitely not over an hour. It did the same thing yesterday. Time for the easy puzzle is accurate.

I feel like there was a missed opportunity to connect the two long answers in the SE.

AS SEEN ON TV, as a bit of ad-speak, and that line from classic Ronco (or was it K-Tel) commercials:
"But wait......THERE'S MORE!!!"

"Act now and get the 'Cap Snaffler!  Snaffles caps, just like that!"

This one was so fun! I love 62A's clue!
I'm gonna go with #1 being the lie on intuition.

Where does the voting stand on the "two truths and a lie" quiz posed by Adrian Johnson in the Constructors' Notes?

My vote for the lie is on #2:  "We both love ice cream."

My reasoning is twofold:
1.  The picture accompanying today's column.  (Is there any other reason to show a picture of ice cream?)
2.  The constructors are clearly masters of the misdirect, so the one that is "obviously true" must be the one that is false.
A TEE is not a part of a golf club

So.....all you guys who have been complaining about the "too-easy" puzzles in recent days:  I hope you're happy.
I'd certainly like to meet the pair who put this doozy together; we could talk about how MANGO TREES was a nice fit for 29D...maybe have a little snicker about all the people who wanted SEVILLE oranges, or how ORIGAMI actually fit at 40D even if it isn't Greek... While you two stay seated (CRISS-CROSS APPLE SAUCE!!)  I could describe how I seriously resisted putting in SAPID even though I know it's a word.  DART doesn't sound very "footbally."

@Deb Amlen

I learned the Latin word "sapere" from the phrase "Sapere aude!" -- "Dare to know!" -- which the philosopher Immanuel Kant said was the motto of the Enlightenment.

Could the same word mean both "to know" and "to taste"???
Indeed it can!  
I'd love to hear an intelligent philologist expound on the connection between these two meanings!
This was a tough one but persistence paid off.

One more puzzle find. A Monday from February 4, 2019 by Ali Gascoigne. Thought this was clever. Four theme answers, straightforwardly clued: TINFOILHAT OUTINFORCE YOUREINFORITNOW BRAINFOODS And then the 'reveal': "Dirt ... or what 17-, 25-, 36- and 48-Across all have?" INSIDEINFO Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/4/2019&g=17&d=A ....

This was one of those times when I learned a whole new word when I filled in the very last square, which was an educated guess.

The guess was the [P] added to the INS in 53A. [P]INS means ‚Äúsaves, as a digital location‚Äù? @Jon
If you're asking for an answer in ethics, it's simple. Don't lie. 
In ethics, the generally held position oscillates between /never/ lying and only lying in extreme circs -- e.g., to hide an innocent from a would-be murderer presently able to carry out that intention if the innocent's location is disclosed. (Remember, some say you can't lie even then. Regrettably, Victim is going to be offed but your moral stance remains intact!)
Calling it "pretending" doesn't make it not-lying, unless you're five. You admit your position would be false, you know it to be false,  but you say no one will care.

There's a common misconception that in American football, the feet are not used.

In fact, on every play, every player uses his feet.  No player is ever seated, lying down or suspended in mid-air by a rope.

The only sports I can think of in which the feet aren't used are e-sports.

(All forms of football--association, both codes of rugby, American, Canadian, Australian, Gaelic) derived from a moblike sport that evolved first into soccer, and then evolved further into the other sports.  These sports were called "football" because, unlike the sports of the nobility, like polo and fox hunting, they were played **on foot**, not on horseback.)

*book*‚Ä¶ you read that right‚Ä¶
of poetry I memorized.

so in the 1970‚Äôs, 
getting 5 whole dollars
*and* - the best part of all -
